best_practices: Start by understanding the user's aesthetic intent, then create an algorithmic philosophy before implementing code
Always use seeded randomness (randomSeed/noiseSeed) for reproducible art generation
Keep the algorithmic philosophy concise (4-6 paragraphs) but emphasize craftsmanship and computational expertise
Use the provided viewer.html template as the exact starting point - keep fixed sections unchanged
Design parameters that emerge naturally from the algorithm, not arbitrary pattern types
Ensure same seed always produces identical output for Art Blocks-style reproducibility
Balance complexity with performance - aim for smooth 60fps if animated
Create self-contained HTML artifacts with everything inline (except p5.js CDN)
Match UI controls precisely to the parameters your algorithm actually uses
Emphasize that the reference/concept should be subtle and sophisticated, not literal
anti_patterns: Creating HTML from scratch instead of using the provided viewer.html template
Copying existing artists' work or creating derivative art that violates copyright
Building static images with random elements instead of true generative algorithms
Forgetting to implement seeded randomness, making art non-reproducible
Adding parameters that don't actually affect the algorithm meaningfully
Using dark themes or custom color schemes instead of Anthropic branding
Creating separate .js files instead of embedding everything in the HTML artifact
Making the conceptual reference too literal or obvious instead of subtle and sophisticated
Writing overly long philosophies (>6 paragraphs) that repeat the same concepts
Treating templates as pattern menus to choose from rather than structural guides

faq.question: What is an algorithmic philosophy?
faq.answer: An algorithmic philosophy is a computational aesthetic movement expressed through code - a manifesto describing how mathematical processes, emergent behavior, and parametric systems create beauty. It guides the implementation by defining the algorithmic approach (flow fields, particle systems, recursion, etc.) rather than prescribing specific visual outcomes.

faq.question: Why use seeded randomness?
faq.answer: Seeded randomness ensures reproducibility - the same seed always produces identical artwork. This is critical for Art Blocks-style generative art where collectors want to preserve specific variations. It also enables seed navigation (prev/next) to explore the parameter space systematically.

faq.question: Can I create 3D generative art?
faq.answer: The skill documentation focuses on 2D p5.js canvas work. While p5.js supports WebGL and 3D rendering, the templates and examples provided are optimized for 2D generative techniques like flow fields, particle systems, and canvas-based rendering.

faq.question: How do I share the generated art?
faq.answer: The output is a self-contained HTML file that works immediately in any browser. You can save it and share the file directly, or it displays as an interactive artifact in Claude.ai. Users can download PNG snapshots using the built-in download functionality.

faq.question: What should parameters control?
faq.answer: Parameters should control fundamental properties of your algorithmic system: quantities (how many elements), scales (size, speed), probabilities, ratios, angles, and thresholds where behavior changes. They should emerge naturally from what the algorithm needs, not be arbitrary pattern selectors.

faq.question: What is the 'subtle conceptual reference'?
faq.answer: The skill emphasizes embedding sophisticated, niche conceptual threads into the algorithm itself - not literal representations. Like a jazz musician quoting another song through harmony, the reference should enhance depth for those who recognize it while everyone else simply experiences masterful generative art. It's the soul woven invisibly into parameters and emergence patterns.

permissions: No special permissions required - runs entirely in browser
